content.body: MikeSmith, do you have any insight into <http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=641>, or know who might?  (FWIW: <http://validator.nu/?doc=http://www.wikipedia.org>)
looks now

AryehGregor: hsivonen would definitely have insight into that, if he had time to look at in detail. but I think his time for validator.nu bug fixing is limited right now. so in the mean time, I can take a look at it unless he beats me to it.
Thanks.  It's not urgent.
OK, I've already been looking at that same code over the weekend, for the other bug you reported
http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=640
I already have a fix written up for that
partial fix
Great.
I'm sure some of the codes are actually wrong.  When I can figure out which ones, I'll talk to our language people and get them replaced with more correct ones.
AryehGregor: actually, most of them are not outright wrong -- there's a number of them that are valid, but deprecated
like "zh-yue" -- that should just be "yue" instead
Yeah, we know about most of those, I think.
We've sort of accreted them over the years.
well, the validator should not actually report those as errors
Once we've set up a wiki, it's a pain to change the domain, and it doesn't really hurt anything to keep it, so we tend to leave it alone.
yeah, understood
("we" not really including me, I'm not a sysadmin and can't change the domains)
It's easy to change the lang="" attribute on that one page, though.
OK. well please leave it for now if you can
until we get this bug resolved
No problem.
It's a good test case.
so anyway, validator.nu should just report those as warnings, not errors
because they are not strictly conformance errors
the problem is, in the current validator.nu datatype-checking code, there's no mechanism for emitting warnings about datatypes of attribute values
it is currently only set up to emit error messages
There are probably other cases where you'd want warnings for attribute values, but I can't think where offhand.
yeah, I'm sure we will find some others, anyway
AryehGregor: so I need to ask hsivonen for some guidance about what he thinks the best way to refine the code to emit warnings
Okay, no problem.  As I say, not urgent.
OK
http://www.bigmouthmedia.com/live/articles/html-5-draft-hyperlink-auditing-and-how-it-will-i.asp/6308/
Is anyone implementing ping?
mozilla has an implementation which they disabled while the spec was unstable
i expect other browsers will implement it in due course
someone expressed interest in implementing it for WebKit, citing content publishers who want to use it, and I asked them to get those publishers to say so on the record
Could it realistically be useful in the near future?  Does it support any kind of useful fallback?
hasn't gotten up to that part of the spec, apparently, or perhaps has just forgotten
it could be useful it you don't care about losing link tracking in browsers that don't support it
it could be useful if you UA-sniff and serve different content to browsers that support it
I think you can use the "ping" IDL attribute to detect from script if ping is supported
mulls over the SHOULD-level UI requirement
I'm pretty sure we would not add UI for hyperlink auditing to MobileSafari
not because I've asked but because we have so very few prefs for it in general
on desktop Safari we'd need good wording
I'm not sure "Enable hyperlink auditing" would be comprehensible
and "Don't let sites track your browsing" would be a lie
my suggestion has been as follows:
have a single trackbar control that goes from "maximum compatibility" to "maximum privacy"
with maybe three notches
the first enables third-party cookies, etc
the third disabled ping, all cookies, etc
the middle one is the default
our only big switch toggle is Private Browsing mode
we would definitely disable ping in that mode, though I'm not sure that satisfies the intent of the requirement
you already have a "third party cookies" pref
i'd remove that and other privacy-related controls and simplify the whole thing to the aforementioned switch
but then, i'm no ui expert
I think the UI issue here is that normal people don't care about these settings and never touch them, but privacy nuts want to know exactly what is happening
sure, but for such small demographics you'd have extensions to expose the details
i'm just talking about the main UI for all users
we don't currently have a way in the UI to block Referer or non-cookie forms of state other than Private Browsing
Safari doesn't currently have extensions (other than unsupported hacks)

I guess based on that, the logical conclusion is that Private Browsing should be the UI to turn off ping, but I suspect some people will want to turn it off without crippling their browsing experience quite that much
I will ask our UI people what they think
is unclear on the other issue
other issue?
I'm not sure why using POST for hyperlink auditing is any worse than the possibility of POSTing a form with .submit(), or using an XMLHttpRequest with POST
it's not
using POST is the right thing to do
I'm looking at the issue tracker issues about hyperlink auditing
I don't actually understand that one
ping has to be a non-idempotent method to work
othermaciej: I am not sure that there is a clear mapping between privacy and ping
for instance, if I'm concerned ping isn't working, i can just force a user through a redirect
ifette: privacy as a general concept, or privacy as in Private Browsing mode?
(and cause the user to incur latency)
othermaciej: the latter
presumably Private Browsing mode would not reveal to the server up front that <a ping> won't do anything
(likewise for any other way of turning it off)
presumably you can figure out that the user is in private browsing mode based on some of the other discussions around local storage and that API being disabled, and so can fall back to redirects :)

I just don't get all the concern about a ping. Great, so you know the user clicked a link... okay. Any messaging to users is going to be deceptive for the majority of them. I can't just have a checkbox that says "disable <a ping>", but if I try to say "disable link tracking"
that would just be dishonest given that there's so many other ways to do it

Frankly, I would much rather say "look, websites can figure out if you clicked on a link. It's been that way for a long time. Live with it. <a ping> lets life move on as it has, but can make your browsing faster
that would be an argument to have no UI at all to turn it off
... by not having to deal with redirects etc"
othermaciej: excellent idea!
ifette: you can detect if the browsers supports ping
Hixie: doesn't that support ifette's argument?
jorlow: how so?

What's the real use case here? What's the concern? If it's "evil google will know all the links I'm clicking", that information is already known, and furthermore if I want to be evil, I can say "If I never got an a ping response with this cookie, then for this cookie don't use a ping and use redirects instead"
this is valuable information to webmasters
if aping isn't supported (as it wouldn't be in private browsing) then the page could just fall back to other methods
they will get it one way or another
ifette, jorlow: if you guys think there should be no UI requirement for ping, not even a SHOULD-level requirement, then you should make that case to Hixie
we might as well make it not suck for users
I will happily do so, if I can find the right thread. I will admit to being swamped via email.
the two main reasons we (google) want ping="" is (a) allowing us to honour user privacy desires without them having to use a cookie to opt-out, and (b) latency improvements from not redirecting.
there is no current email thread
so if the browser supports ping, we wouldn't route around it being disabled
ifette: I'm just saying that if you think there should be no browser UI to turn it off, then you shouldn't argue with me, because I didn't make or ask for the spec requirement to have it
We wouldn't route around it, others might
hm....i guess it's true that aping makes it easier for sites to "do the right thing" WRT privacy
I was only looking at it from the "evil" side of things
i'm sure there are sites who would indeed route around it
but hey, that's their problem
othermaciej: wasn't trying to argue with you, was simply stating that tying it to private browsing might not make sense
it's true that UI to turn it off won't help you against a malicious site
ifette: if there was UI for it at all, then I think tying it to private browsing would make sense, because private browsing tries to turn off everything
in that case, i suppose linking it with private browsing might make sense
at least in safari

It seems to me that the following are probable: 1) if a ping isn't reliable / everyone turns it off because it's something that the media gets hyped up about like cookies, no one will use it and just use redirects instead 2) any option presented to users would be unintelligable and over promise or seem like a no-brainer to check c) none of this will matter to "evil" sites
under private browsing, a malicious site could tell what links you follow off their page by other means, but could not tie it back to you due to lack of cookies
though to be fair, we don't yet have a way to turn off your IP address
well, cookies can be turned off, but in practice very few people do
othermaciej: i view private browsing as "don't leave a trace of what I do on my computer", not "please use TOR and make me as anonymous as possible"
if it's "something that the media gets hyped up about like cookies", then people won't turn it off.
othermaciej: if you say "private browsing mode turns off <a ping>", what do you say to a real user?
most sites consider cookies reliable enough for their needs, even though there are a small minority of users who turn them off entirely
a few sites use Flash cookies instead, though you can turn off plugins to get around those

i think if the preference is a serious one like i proposed earlier, and not just one that disabled just this feature, that it won't be turned off just for the sake of it, but only by people who actually want their privacy protected
ifette: our private browsing explanation dialog is hardly a paragon of clarity as is

othermaciej: Yes, people still use cookies, not the best example. Was trying to say that it's something real users don't well understand, and that in general when you mention cookies people think "bad" without understanding
othermaciej: :)
>95% of people will never change any privacy-related preferences
Hixie: wtf. "Want their privacy protected" -- if you say that to users, what user is going to say "No, I don't want my privacy protected, let's leave this unchecked" :)
on the other hand, lack of ping would probably break the web much less visibly than lack of cookies or lack of plugins
I guess my biggest beef is that I don't want people permanently using "private mode" because tat's not a good user experience
so I resist tying the option to that
ifette: hence my proposal, which isn't such a checkbox. see above.
I don't think anyone permanently uses Private Browsing mode, or would
but I don't think a separate setting for <a ping> is worth its weight in pixels
btw, where can i find a copy of the latest 'a ping' proposal?
and I don't think Hixie's suggested tri-state setting would be very understandable
jorlow: it's in the HTML5 spec
jorlow: http://whatwg.org/html5
look for "hyperlink auditing"
Correct -- but then there comes a question, if it's only tied to private browsing mode, is that really a good option?
if i'm a user freaked out by a ping
private browsing mode does lots of things that we don't offer as normal user settings
ahh...thanks http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/history.html#hyperlink-auditing
sigh, sure
if you're a user freaked out by ping, then you get an extension that gives you fine-grained control
if users really freaked out about it, we would probably add a separate setting
most users aren't going to have a clue or care
if too many people used the setting, then it would indeed undermine the value of the feature
the sad part is that tying it to private browsing mode might have an opposite effect
let's say people use private browisng mode for porn
but if that many people are that freaked out about it, then omitting the setting would just make browsers with <a ping> lose market share
that would imply that porn sites would not get good results from a ping
and therefore would still use redirects
and so the effect of turning it off in private browsing mode would be minimal
well, users shouldn't be freaked out....because nothing is worse than the state of things today
they shouldn't be, but the concern about having a preference is based on the theory that a lot of them will
but of course, that doesn't necessarily mean the media won't write a story to the contrary

I think my preference is really to say "Look, sites can know what link you click. That's the way it is today, we're not changing anything except reducing some latency, live with it. If you want more controls over your data, let's have a more comprehensive discussion and figure soething out"
my expectation: only a small minority of users will care enough to take action
Well, maybe the preference can be a check box with a somewhat cryptic name
failing to give those people a means to take action without switching browsers will generate a huge amount of negative PR
i mean, most users don't even know what a cookie is...even today
jorlow: try getting that past ben ;-)
othermaciej: Yes, except here "take action" is kinda lame
'disable hyperlink auditing'....if users really care, they'll know what it is
and users won't turn it off in a misguided attempt at 'privacy'
ifette: even if it's a UI placebo, failing to have it will probably make a vocal minority very upset
othermaciej: wouldn't be the first time
that's probably true........
othermaciej: we took out the options to enable sslv2
othermaciej: and all sorts of other crap options
othermaciej: e.g. we don't let users disable javascript
othermaciej: but we're supposed to let users disable <a ping> ?
just tie it to the same as the third party cookie pref, like i suggested
along with the other privacy related features
Hixie: Where is your suggestion
Hixie: Want to make sure I don't misinterpret it. I really don't like tying it to third party cookies if I understand you correctly, as they have nothing to do with each other
that way people who really do value privacy over compatibility get what they want, and the others don't change the pref unknowingly
ifette: Safari has very few prefs, and I wouldn't be keen on adding one for this
Hixie: I may not want some advertiser to know what I'm doing on Google, but I'm fine with Google knowing what I'm searching for on Google
http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20090908#l-134
ifette: ^
ty
Hixie: in the Safari UI, we don't like to face people with an arbitrary tradeoff with unknowable consequences
like, we'd never have a slider with "speed" on one end and "security" on the other
Hixie: eep
othermaciej: you already have "Accept cookies: ( ) Always ( ) Never ( ) Only sites I visit"
+1 maciej
othermaciej: which is pretty much as arbitrary
sure, but we present that in terms of concrete result, not "more compatible" vs "more private"
likewise we don't present "Enable Java" as "Make some sites work, but damn will they be slow and there's probably horrible security consequences"

Hixie: If I don't let users turn off something as major as JavaScript, I'm sure as hell not letting them turn off some random thing like <a ping>. Down that road lies the path to hell. I am also not tying it to Incognito, as I think again it has little to do with it and won't actually solve any problem
or "Enable plug-ins" as "Support casual games and annoying ads"
Hixie: I'm happy to send an email, but I would not support anything beyond a MAY for the option
(and frankly saying that you MAY have a checkbox option is really not saying much)
othermaciej: ok, then label the three notches as what they disabled or enable :-)
Frankly, unless you're talking a per-site basis, I don't know that options about Flash or Java make sense

ifette: it would be politically inconvenient for me to change the "should" to a "may", but i don't think it matters -- "should" just means you have to have a good reason, and "We want our UA to be usable" is a good reason
I browse with Java turned off all the time
othermaciej: Java yes, I concede you that. Flash, not so much.
well, not having Flash is livable on my iPhone, probably not so much on a desktop browser
othermaciej: stop making good points :P
we need a stalking horse browser to ship <a ping> and take all the flak
but we do get frequent user requests to augment the general "Enable plug-ins" setting with a separate "Enable Flash", so they can turn off just Flash
roc: I think ifette just volunteered Chrome - presumably with the catchy slogan, "What's the concern? Evil google will know all the links I'm clicking?"
works for me
othermaciej: While I might be fine with that string, I'm pretty sure legal would shoot it down :(
on a completely different front, i'm working through some microdata feedback
and i have to say
it's really
really
really hard to do a good job when you care so little about the technology
Can we add some more markup?
<main> or something?
and plese, let's have some more OWL stuff in there
(sorry, I'm re-living some nightmares, waiting for @jorlow to slap me awake)
ifette: what are you talking about?  it's 1:47pm...you're still sleeping?
I think we should upgrade Web Ontology Language to Ontology Representation Language for You
because I'm pretty sure there's no better OWL than ORLY
othermaciej: you feeling any better than you were at the end of last week?
MikeSmith: I'm down from "violently severely sick" to "really sick"
geez
any idea what it is? virus?
probably
some sort of flu I think, hopefully not one of the animal flavored varieties
I don't have a fever any more but I am still really congested, throat is sore, stomach somewhat upset, etc
Saturday was really terrible though, I hadn't realized how excruciating it is to fly with a bad cold/flu - what with the air pressure changes
yeah
eww...yeah  :-(
the only time i've ever gone to the doctor for flu like symptoms is when i had to fly
and i was sure glad i did
well, this was after getting hopped up on all the non-prescription meds I could get in the middle of the night in Cambridge
(thank goodness for that 7-Eleven in Tech Square)
yeah, that place seems to be about the only thing close by that's open late
I ended up going there around 2 AM in hopes of cold medicine and fluids
there were a bunch of MIT kids there
reminds me of my younger days
I'm glad such archectypes as Purple Haired Girl, Guy with Nerdy Slogan T-Shirt, Asian Guy in Cargo Shorts and Hippie Girl in Long Dress are still to be found at the ol' Institute
heh
man, the bottom part of movie posters are a huge pain in the asss to typeset
i wonder what tools they use to do it
you mean where they have all the tiny little mandatory credits?
yeah
what is so hard about typesetting it?
the "EDITED BY" bit
check the bottom of http://www.comingsoon.net/imageGallery/Ninja_Assassin/large/hr_Ninja_Assassin_poster.jpg out
look for "PRODUCTION DESIGNER"
notice the following:
1. the gap between the start of the longest of those two words to the word before it is consistent across all such cases
2. the top of PRODUCTION lines up with the top of the line, the bottom of DESIGNER with the bottom of the line
3. the line height of that two-line thingy is proportional to the line height of the main text
I presume this is all down to careful selection of font sizes
Hixie: are you trying to replicate the layout using CSS?
hsivonen: actually i was trying to do it using pages, but it would also be quite hard to get right in CSS
i actually can't find a non-hacky way to do it in Pages
presumably in a layout tool with guide lines this is all pretty simple
othermaciej: well you can't just overlap text, since if you then edit any one part of it, you'd have to manually retypeset the rest
othermaciej: so it has to be something that supports nested two-line text
which Pages doesn't
in CSS you can do it using display:inline-block, but then getting the font sizes right is impossible
since you don't know your font metrics ahead of time
I guess you'd want something like FrameMaker
i guess
I'm not overly familiar with Pages
but yeah, you're right, this is a typographical oddity that you rarely see anywhere but movie posters
hsivonen: if/when you have some time, I wanted to ask you if you think it would be worthwhile to add ability to the validator.nu for emitting warnings to the datatype-checking code
hsivonen: as opposed to just errors
MikeSmith: it could well be worthwhile. the hard question is how to do it
yeah
the datatypes are not supposed to have side effects
ah
and in principle, it's ok for Jing to call into a datatype, get an error, call into another datatype, not get an error and prefer the latter and not show the first error
also, in principle, the Java interface stuff should be such that the datatype jar can be used in a vanilla Jing
hsivonen: OK, I begin to see now
the whole thing has been designed for a boolean notion of validity without any shades in between
that's the real problem
I'd have thought that the bottom of those movie posters is laid out completely in Photoshop or Illustrator
in other words, manually, with a lot of effort and pain
hsivonen: I have come to think that think that boolean notion of validity is a serious flaw of grammar-based schema checking
MikeSmith: maybe filing a bug against upstream Jing could elicit some insights
OK, I can try that
MikeSmith: I agree with your observation about grammars
Hixie: OmniGraffle may work better for this use case than Pages
possibly
hsivonen: the specific problem that led me to ask about this is the bug about language tags that AryehGregor reported a couple of days ago
http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=640
I would expect handcrafted SVG in #whatwg.
you'd expect SVG in #whatwg? :-)
ttepasse: Pages is already shiny Cocoa payware
s/SVG/canvas 2d/ ;)
MikeSmith: given the constraints, I suggest making stuff that should be conforming not emit any messages for now even if it's obsolete/deprecated
which reminds me that I should redeploy V.nu
Any chance you can use Ruby, with appropriate CSS to get the sizing right?
(re: "Production Designer")
(yes, it's a bit of a hack, but it's the only thing I can think of that might let you get two lines on one line)
display:inline-box would too

hsivonen: not emitting messages for those cases seems like declaring defeat to me. I would personally really rather not do that unless you think there's no practical way to work around it. even if it ends up being kind of a messy way
MikeSmith: ok
ifette, heycam: the problem with CSS is getting the font metrics right; the layout itself is easy to achieve
hsivonen: I'm willing to spend some time on it this week at least. If we can't some workaround figured out, then I guess can comment out the reporting about the deprecated stuff
hsivonen: so here's a stupid idea: we include some magic substring in the NewDatatypeException message for warning-level cases
and that substring would show up in messages if anybody used the datatypes outside of the v.nu system
but the error-reporting backend could check for that magic substring and then make those messages warnings instead of errors
I don't know how do-able that is in the current backend. or whether you think it'd even be a good idea to do it at all
MikeSmith: It's easy to put a flag on the exception so that the RELAX NG semantics of the result are "invalid" but the V.nu front end downgrades the message type (and the validity outcome)
MikeSmith: what's hard is making the RELAX NG semantics be that the result is valid
MikeSmith: I guess this is a "theoretical purity" kind of point
MikeSmith: I think you can't detect it with the current schema
MikeSmith: but in principle, it changes the generic reuse characteristics of the datatype lib
MikeSmith: maybe in this case, it's anyway the best solution to make the exception have a flag that tells V.nu to downgrade the message
It seems like there are no exceptions to the rule that non-ASCII supersets are security holes: http://mail.apps.ietf.org/ietf/charsets/msg01846.html
I don't think browsers can stop accepting UTF-16 though
hsivonen: OK, I see what you're saying about the problem still being to have RELAX NG semantic be that it's valid
hsivonen: so instead, what about just having the datatype library not throw the exception at all if its used outside of validator.nu?
I don't know how doable that might be
MikeSmith: that's a possibility. (you could still detect the implementation by feeding V.nu a contrived custom schema, but I guess that doesn't matter in practice)
MikeSmith: You could have a Java system property for toggling this behavior
OK. seems like that route is probably the best to try
unless we can manage to come up with something better in the mean time, I'll work on writing up a patch for that
some time this week
I've repointed the validator.nu and html5.validator.nu hostnames on the DNS level
(so that I can do a dist upgrade on the other server)
I hope nothing breaks...
MikeSmith: I *think* I have deployed your recent changes
hsivonen: thanks. fwiw, I've been running from my workspace (with my commits) with no problems. So I don't think those will break anything.
I didn't sync up yet to Sam's change, though
wow, running the microwave totally killed my wifi network
i wonder if the other times i have dropouts of the network is because of neighbours running microwaves
gah
so hard to write an intro section for microdata
complete this sentence: "Microdata allows you to layer lists of name-value pairs on top of Web pages, so that"
...in a way that makes Web authors think "ooh, cool"
unicorns can sprinkle magic fairy dust everywhere, causing world peace and happiness
it also has to be accurate.
Oh? I assumed that was accurate given the intensity of the feeling that the topic has generated
i believe a lot of people believe that it is accurate, yes
but sadly it is not
AH
s/AH/Ah/
here's what i came up with:
Microdata allows you to layer lists of name-value pairs on top of Web
pages, so that JavaScript scripts, search engines, and other tools can
extract that data from the page directly instead of you having to
provide this data in a separate file.
"Microdata is a mechanism apply structured-data objects within web pages…" ?
your "this" doesn't match your "that"
‘to apply’, even
benward: the "what" is easy, it's the "so that..." part that's hard
jgraham: did s/this data/it/
Hixie: you may want to say something about "reliably" extracting the data from the page to contrast with more hackish sorts of "screen scraping" extraction
just be honest and say "Microdata allows you to add additional, mostly useless metadata in a web page so that you can feel good about contributing to growth of the Semantic Web"
“Microdata allows you to easily add machine-readable arbitrary data as name-value pairs to web pages”…?
boblet: that's still just the "what"
Lachy: see, this is why you're not in marketing
Hixie: indeed, it's hard to write accurate marketing intros in specs. Doing what the XHTML2 WG's specs have is easier.
Lachy: that won't provide the users in this usability study with adequate incentive for us to get useful results
hsivonen: it's not for a spec, it's for the intro we give to the usability study participants
othermaciej: now i have:
Microdata allows you to layer lists of name-value pairs on top of Web
pages, so that JavaScript scripts, search engines, and other tools can
extract that data from the page directly, instead of you having to
provide it in a separate file, or them having to use screen scraping.
Hixie: ah
Hixie: that's pretty good -- adding a concrete example might help too
oh they're getting a whole bunch of those
oh, I thought it was for the spec.
all righty then
othermaciej: http://damowmow.com/playground/microdata/001/
hopes the participants in this study don't read the logs
…“This data can then be easily accessed by scripts, search engines and other tools, giving authors a simple yet open-ended way to extend HTML”
jgraham: if they do, they're far too close to the project :-)
Hixie, http://damowmow.com/playground/microdata/001/blog.html seems to be lacking the microdata
is there any easy way for me to know what browsers support features that have been pulled out of the html5 spec?
for example workers
boblet: closer, but it fails at the end there where it turns into blue sky nonsense :-)
wonders if he really understands Microdata enough to be contributing :)
har
boblet: don't worry, i don't understand it enough either
Lachy: -annotated files have it
oh
jorlow: asking, or testing
all us designer-y types love blue-sky nonsense ;-) well, depending on the shade of blue of course

jorlow: in the case of Workers, I think the answer is recent WebKit-based browsers and recent Gecko-based browsers (most notably Safair, Chrome and Firefox, assuming Chrome has actually shipped the support)
othermaciej: it's shipping in chrome 3
which is in beta
so no opera?
I don't believe it's in Opera yet, but testing Opera 10 would tell more definitively
and it's too bad we don't have the html5 spec annotations for these others specs...  :-/
I wouldn't put too much faith in those annotations being up to date in any case
othermaciej: well, it's just a presentation to googlers....so I don't feel like putting in that much effort  :-)
Microdata is primarily a way to extend HTML’s data structures though… right? To add data that can‘t be included via a predefined method like an existing element…
thanks for the pointers tho
boblet: no, it's a way to overlay another datastructure on top of an HTML document
boblet: it doesn't extend the data structures of the page itself
what hsivonen said
Hixie: those seem like good examples
cool
Hixie: you should ask the RDFa TF to review your study setup before hand
too bad the blog one has to rely so much on invisible or duplicate data
hsivonen: i'll be lucky if i've finished the material before the study starts
othermaciej: well if you want to encode data that's not in the page, there's not much choice
unless you mean something else
hsivonen: thanks for the clarification
oh btw there’s been a big uptick of interest in HTML5 in Japan in the last month
yeah, I guess a lot of it wouldn't have reasonably been in the page
the only obvious duplication was the title itemprop that was also in a title attribute
somewhat surprisingly
othermaciej: hm, yeah. none of the proposals we're going to be testing have a way around that.
othermaciej: if you have an idea to fix that i can try to
put it in one of hte variants
do you have a list of the variants posted anywhere?
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/temp
and out of curiosity, what's the study methodology? will the test subjects be asked to add the annotations using various syntax options??
various things, the details are still being worked out, but basically: given some intro material, look at this example, can you describe what the annotations are?
given this page, can you add these annotations?
